Well, when I look at tsuba priced in the high three figues and above on the usual dealer websites, and they resemble $200 Ebay tsubas in form and basic aesthetic quality, but seem somehow peculiarly more beautiful, more magnificent, downright wrapped in glory, like the advantageously lit men's clothing in the windows of J. Press,  I figure those dealers know something I don't know about how to gussy a tsuba up.  Just like the guy who photographed his rusty Akasaka tsuba on an orange background, and then sold it to me.  There are special skills and tricks of the trade. 


----- Original Message ----- 
  From: steven 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, September 24, 2004 1:34 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Primped/doctored tsuba


  Hi Bob,

  Yes, this is a great site... :o).  I have spent quite a bit of time here, 
  and it's a wealth of information, no doubt.  I think what I'm looking 
  for, though, is to actually see some good close-up photos of a 
  waxed, lacquered, or otherwise primped tsuba.  Sometimes it's 
  easier to understand when a piece is doctored via visuals than  
  by desciption only...  Thanks much for the response, Bob.

  Steve
